awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Headwater stream networks in a warming world: predicting heterotrophic ecosystem function using theory, multi-scale temperature manipulations and modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's river systems receive, transport, store, and break down a substantial proportion of the dead plant material produced in terrestrial ecosystems. Many of the steps in the breakdown of this organic matter are greatly affected by water temperature, which is increasing along with air temperature globally. While the effects of temperature on some of these steps are understood relatively well at small scales, it remains an open question how they interact as a complex, integrated ecosystem-level process to drive the effects of rising temperatures at the large spatial and temporal scales over which Earth's river systems operate. Consequently, research is needed that tests the effects of temperature on organic matter breakdown in whole ecosystems, with the explicit goal of scaling up these results to understand how entire river reaches and networks process organic matter. This project will use data from temperature manipulations at multiple spatial and temporal scales to: 1) inform ecological theory that uses basic principles to understand how the effects of temperature scale from individual organisms to entire ecosystems; and 2) build a model that simulates the effects of temperature on organic matter processing in an entire forest stream network. This research is important because rising temperatures may alter the global biogeochemical role of streams and rivers in currently unpredictable ways, making the results useful in the future management of river health. An education program will be an integral part of this project and will include the development of a citizen science project, as well as training of undergraduates, graduate students and research technicians.
	Fieldwork for this project will take place at the Coweeta Hydrologic Laboratory, North Carolina, U.S.A., a site with a decades-long history of research on organic matter processing in stream ecosystems. The first objective is to understand how warming affects the organisms (fungi and invertebrates) that are critically important in organic matter breakdown in streams. This component of the project will combine detailed laboratory-based studies of fungi, experiments in heated streamside channels and the warming of an entire reach of a small forest stream to understand how higher temperatures change community structure of fungal and animal decomposers. The second objective is to use the various temperature manipulations to understand how temperature changes pathways and rates of organic matter processing in streams and rivers. The fates of organic matter will be studied using laboratory investigations, streamside channels, and field experiments combined with organic matter budgets and food web descriptions in the experimentally warmed stream and a matching reference stream. The results of these first two objectives will be combined with extensive existing datasets available at the Coweeta site to inform the final objective: construction of an ecological model that predicts the effects of warming on organic matter processing in an entire stream network. This model will also allow incorporation of other important factors that could potentially change in the future, such as precipitation and the relative quality of organic matter that enters stream ecosystems. Together, this research will provide much needed information about how warming influences the important biogeochemical role of streams and rivers.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of our research was to understand and predict the consequences of climate warming for carbon cycling, including the metabolism of terrestrial-derived material like leaves that fall from trees in autumn, in headwater stream networks. To achieve this goal, the Virginia Tech collaborators on this multi-university project tracked whole-stream metabolism and carbon biogeochemistry in one experimentally warmed and one reference stream at Coweeta Hydrologic Laboratory (NC, USA) and two non-perennial headwater streams in Jefferson National Forest (VA, USA). We collected high-frequency dissolved oxygen, temperature, and other water chemistry data over multiple years, and analyzed those data using statistical and process-based models to estimate rates of stream metabolism (i.e., photosynthesis and respiration) and carbon fluxes (i.e., emissions and downstream export). We integrated measurements of CO2 and CH4 emissions from different parts of the Coweeta basin to place the role of forested mountain stream corridors, including intermittent vernal pools, in the context of broader landscape carbon budgets.

There did not appear to be an effect of our experimental warming treatment on whole-stream metabolism at Coweeta, but low rates of photosynthesis and high turbulence in these ecosystems hinders our ability to detect seasonal and storm flow consequences for whole-stream metabolism, and model development is ongoing to improve our ability to generate high-quality metabolism estimates from ecosystems like Coweeta streams. Appalachian headwater streams were always a source of CO2 to the atmosphere (likely fueled by high-CO2 groundwater inputs more than by in-stream respiration), but they were only sometimes a source of CH4 to the atmosphere. One Coweeta stream was frequently undersaturated with CH4 with respect to atmospheric CH4 concentrations, which means that stream is a 'CH4 sink' in the context of ecosystem and landscape carbon budgets. This result places forested some Appalachian headwater streams in the 'exception' category of the growing body of literature suggesting most streams and rivers are supersaturated with CH4 (and therefore, 'CH4 sources'). The presence of intermittent waterways, whether vernal pools adjacent to streams or stream channels that dry up into isolated pools, enhances the likelihood that stream corridors will be a net source of both CO2 and CH4 to the atmosphere. Changes in stream flow variability and intermittency due to climate change may override the effects of warming on Appalachian stream biogeochemical processes, including whole-stream metabolism.

In addition to supporting data collection, research presentations, and peer-reviewed publications, this project directly supported the professional development of one Virginia Tech PhD student, two National Science Foundation Research Experiences for Undergraduates (NSF REU) fellows, two additional undergraduate researchers at Virginia Tech, and several other early career researchers who visited Coweeta or Jefferson National Forest to assist with data collection at different stages of the project. PI Hotchkiss also worked with K-12 educators in Virginia to support lesson development and student training in sensor data collection/analyses, which included virtual classroom visits to talk about whole-ecosystem experiments, environmental sensors, water quality, climate change, attending college, and careers in science. All undergraduate researchers funded by this grant are continuing their professional development as early career scientists; current positions held by undergraduates who collaborated on this project through Virginia Tech include: Master's student in Public Health, PhD student in Environmental Engineering Sciences and NSF GRFP (Graduate Research Fellowship Program) awardee, Biological Sciences Master's student, and Environmental Scientist at a consulting agency. The graduate student supported on this project was awarded their PhD in 2023 and is now the Assistant Director of Undergraduate Research at Virginia Tech, a position motivated by their collaborations with and mentorship of undergraduate students as part of this project.
